Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Interrogating and Exploiting the Hydrodynamics of Concentrated Emulsions for Droplet Microfluidics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1454542
PI: Sindy Tang, Stanford University

This CAREER project addresses the hydrodynamics of concentrated emulsions in microchannel flows. Typically in these flows, the droplets become closely packed, and they can coalesce with each other or break apart. In many applications of microfluidic systems, the drops contain chemical reagents or biological samples, and it is imperative to track the individual motion of drops through the microfluidic device. If the drops rearrange their order or breakup, tracking them becomes impossible. This project will identify flow regimes in which drops retain their relative spatial arrangements even when the flow takes the drops through microchannels that contain changes in their cross-sectional shapes. The results of the project will be useful to practitioners who design microfluidic systems for a variety of applications in engineering, biological sciences, and medicine. In addition, results from the research will be used in the development of a new course for engineering undergraduates as well as in the development of demonstration modules and video presentations for K-12 students.

The project will examine the motion of concentrated emulsions in flow through microchannels with confining geometries. Preliminary results demonstrate an interesting flow regime where the spatial arrangement of drops that move through a channel containing a contraction is exactly reversible when the direction of the flow is changed and another regime that results in a stochastic breakup of drops. The goals of the proposal are to characterize these regimes parametrically, identify the cause of drop breakup, and to generate design rules for devices that require drops to move through microfluidic devices maintaining precisely the sequential order of drops through the entire device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project addresses the hydrodynamics of concentrated emulsions in microchannel flows. Typically in these flows, the droplets become closely packed, and they can coalesce with each other or break apart. In many applications of microfluidic systems, the drops contain chemical reagents or biological samples, and it is imperative to track the individual motion of drops through the microfluidic device. If the drops rearrange their order or breakup, tracking them becomes impossible.

 

The major outcome of this project is the identification of the physics of how these crowded drops flow in confined microscale geometries. The drops transition from a solid-like to a liquid-like behavior when the applied flow rate increases. At slow flow conditions, the drops exhibit periodic flow patterns that can be explained by treating the emulsion as the extrusion of a soft crystal. Their paths are predictable and can be easily tracked. At fast flow conditions, the drop paths are more unpredictable, and the drops can become unstable and undergo break-up into two daughter drops as they pinch off each other in the confined geometry. Understanding the interaction of the drops has led to new approaches and design rules to suppress droplet break-up, including the use of nanoparticles as droplet stabilizers, the reduction of the volume fraction of the drops, and the introduction of an obstacle close to the exit of the channel to induce a passive ordering of the drops.

 

The results of the project are useful to practitioners who design microfluidic systems for a variety of applications in engineering, biological sciences, and medicine. Applications developed include using these drops to increase the sensitivity and speed of the detection of bacteria causing diseases including tuberculosis, sepsis, and antibiotic resistance. In addition, the results can find potential use in extrusion-based 3D printing of concentrated emulsions (or foams) for generating hierarchical or porous materials, where emulsions are pushed through a narrow nozzle. The results from this project could be applied to prevent break-up and preserve the integrity of this class of 3D printed materials. Finally, results from the project are used in the curriculum of engineering undergraduates and outreach activities for the general public.


Last Modified: 02/16/2021
Modified by: Sindy Ky Tang

The drops transition from a solid-like to a liquid-like behavior when the applied flow rate increases. At slow flow conditions, the drops exhibit periodic flow patterns that can be explained by treating the emulsion as the extrusion of a soft crystal. Their paths are predictable and can be easily tracked.
